narrative: From a penniless orphan in the Caribbean to a Founding Father of the United States, Alexander Hamilton's life is a testament to relentless ambition and intellect. As the first Secretary of the Treasury, he architected the nation's financial system and defended the Constitution, though his life was ultimately cut short in a tragic duel.

slides.title: Humble Beginnings in the Caribbean
slides.content: Born out of wedlock in Nevis and orphaned at a young age, Hamilton worked as a clerk to survive. His intellect was undeniable, and after writing a vivid account of a hurricane, local leaders raised funds to send him to the American colonies for an education.
slides.imagePrompt: A hyper-realistic 18th-century scene in a Caribbean port town, featuring a young Alexander Hamilton writing in a ledger book at a wooden desk, with a view of ships and a tropical storm gathering in the background, warm lantern lighting.

slides.title: Washington's Right-Hand Man
slides.content: During the Revolutionary War, Hamilton served as George Washington's aide-de-camp, managing correspondence and strategy. He eventually convinced Washington to give him a field command, leading a decisive bayonet charge at the Battle of Yorktown.
slides.imagePrompt: A scene inside a military command tent during the Revolutionary War, George Washington and Alexander Hamilton standing over a map, Hamilton pointing out a strategy, illuminated by candlelight, soldiers visible outside.

slides.title: The Pen Behind the Constitution
slides.content: Hamilton was a staunch advocate for a strong central government and attended the Constitutional Convention. To ensure ratification, he authored the majority of the Federalist Papers, a collection of essays that remain the primary interpretation of the Constitution today.
slides.imagePrompt: Close-up of a quill pen writing on parchment paper, the title 'The Federalist' visible, surrounded by stacks of paper and books, with a blurred background of the Constitutional Convention hall, high definition.

slides.title: Architect of the Economy
slides.content: As the first Secretary of the Treasury, Hamilton established the First Bank of the United States and the US Mint. He successfully argued that the federal government should assume state debts, unifying the nation's finances and establishing creditworthiness.
slides.imagePrompt: Detailed illustration of the first US Treasury, blending 18th-century architecture with superimposed animated gold coins and financial charts showing the assumption of state debt, symbolizing economic structure.
slides.videoPrompt: A 5-second motion graphic showing 13 distinct streams of coins (state debts) merging into a single, strong golden pillar (Federal Treasury), with a graph line rising upwards to symbolize economic growth.

slides.title: Political Rivalries
slides.content: Hamilton's Federalist vision clashed sharply with Thomas Jefferson and James Madison, leading to the formation of America's first political parties. These intense ideological debates shaped early American politics but also created lifelong enemies for Hamilton.
slides.imagePrompt: A split-screen composition with an artistic, oil-painting style; on the left, Alexander Hamilton in a red velvet coat, on the right, Thomas Jefferson in a blue coat, both looking intense, with a blurred background of Congress Hall.

slides.title: The Duel at Weehawken
slides.content: Long-standing political tensions with Vice President Aaron Burr culminated in a duel on July 11, 1804, in Weehawken, New Jersey. Hamilton fired his pistol into the air, but Burr aimed to kill, mortally wounding Hamilton who died the next day.
slides.imagePrompt: A somber, misty morning landscape on the cliffs of Weehawken overlooking the Hudson River, silhouettes of two men standing far apart facing each other, period clothing, holding flintlock pistols, dramatic lighting.

slides.title: A Lasting Legacy
slides.content: Despite his early death, Hamilton's impact is undeniable, from the financial systems he built to his face on the ten-dollar bill. His story has seen a massive cultural resurgence recently, solidifying his status as a key architect of the modern United States.
slides.imagePrompt: A montage image featuring a marble statue of Alexander Hamilton, overlaid with the texture of the US ten-dollar bill, and a modern skyline of New York City in the background, representing the endurance of his work.
